name: 電影史
goals: 增進學生對電影史的認識。
培養學生對電影史作品的詮釋能力。
培養學生對電影史作品相關議題的分析能力。
syllabus:
**History of Film**

Considered by its inventors as an “invention without a future,” cinema has become today one of the most powerful generator of images. The objective of the course is to provide a selective survey on the history of cinema from the proto-history of the moving image until today. Each session will focus on paradigmatic works, retracing the most critical stages of the history of cinema. Special attention will be given to the forms, motifs, and genres that have distinguished the cinematic medium from the other visual arts. 

**Outlines**

Week 1: Introduction

Weeks 2: 1900-1914: The Cinema of Attraction

Bibliography:

*   François Albéra (ed.), _Cinema Beyond Film: Media Epistemology in the Modern Era_, Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press, 2010
*   André Gaudreault, Nicolas Dulac and Santiago Hidalgo (eds.), _A Companion to Early Cinema_, London: Wiley Blackwell, 2012
*   Wanda Strauven (ed.), _The Cinema of Attractions Reloaded_, Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press, 2006
*   André Gaudreault (ed.), _American Cinema, 1890-1909: Themes and Variations_, New Brunswick: Rutgers University Press, 2009

Week 3: 1915: The Origins of Narration: D.W. Griffith

Bibliography:

*   Tom Gunning, _D.W. Griffith and the Origins of American Narrative Film: The Early Years at Biograph_, Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 1991

Week 4: 1920s: Theories of Montage. Sergei Eisenstein /Lev Kuleshov / Dziga Vertov

Bibliography:

*   Mike O'Mahony, _Sergei Eisenstein_, London: Reaktion Books, 2008
*   Sergei Eisenstein, _Selected Works_, London: I.B. Tauris, 3 vols., 2010

Weeks 4: 1920s- 1930s: Cinema and Avant-Gardes

Bibliography: 

*   Richard Abel (ed.), _French Film Theory and Criticism: A History/Anthology, 1907-1939_, 2 vols., Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1988
*   Bruce Elder, _Dada, Surrealism, And the Cinematic Effect_, Waterloo: Wilfrid Laurier University Press, 2013
*   Jeffrey Skoller, _Shadows, Specters, Shards: Making History in Avant-Garde Film_, Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press, 2005

Week 5: 1920s-1930s: “Expressionism” I: Fritz Lang

Bibliography:

*   Tom Gunning, _The Films of Fritz Lang: Allegories of Vision and Modernity_, London: BFI, 2000

Week 6: 1940s-1950s: “Expressionism” II: Film Noir

Bibliography:

*   Edward Dimendberg, _Film Noir and the Spaces of Modernity_, Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 2004
*   Stephen Faison, _Existentialism, Film Noir, and Hard-Boiled Fiction_, Amherst: Cambria Press, 2008
*   Dan Flory, Philosophy, _Black Film, Film Noir_, University Park: Pennsylvania State University Press, 2008

Week 7: 1944-1952: Neorealism

Bibliography:

*   Dudley Andrew and Hervé Joubert-Laurencin (eds.), _Opening Bazin: Postwar Film Theory and Its Afterlife_, New York: Oxford University Press, 2011
*   Saverio Giovacchini and Robert Sklar Global (eds.), _Neorealism: The Transnational History of a Film Style_, Jackson: University Press of Mississippi, 2012

Weeks 8-9: 1950s: Alfred Hitchcock and the Classic Grammar of Cinema

Bibliography:

*   Francois Truffaut and Helen G. Scott, _Hitchcock_, New York: Simon and Schuster, 1984 
*   Thomas M Leitch, (ed.), _A companion to Alfred Hitchcock_, Chichester, West Sussex: Wiley-Blackwell, 2011

Week 10: 1950s-1960s: The Golden Age of Japanese Cinema

Bibliography:

*   Laura Lee, _Japanese Cinema Between Frames_, London: Palgrave Macmillan, 2017
*   Alastair Phillips and Julian Stringer (eds.), _Japanese Cinema: Texts and Contexts_, London and New York: Routledge, 2007

Weeks 11: 1960s: Cinema and Modernity I: Michelangelo Antonioni

Bibliography:

*   Matilde Nardelli, _Antonioni and the Aesthetics of Impurity. Remaking the Image in the 1960s_, Edinburgh, University of Edinburgh Press, 2020
*   Laura Rascaroli and John David Rhodes (eds.), _Antonioni. Centenary Essays_, London: Palgrave MacMillan and BFI, 2011

Weeks 12-13: 1960s-1970s: Cinema and Modernity II: The French New Wave

Bibliography:

*   Michel Marie, _The French New Wave: An Artistic School_, Malden: Blackwell., 2003
*   Geneviève Sellier, _Masculine Singular: French New Wave Cinema_, Durham: Duke University Press, 2008

Weeks 14: 1980s-1990s: The Taiwanese “New Wave.” Edward Yang, Hou Hsiao-Hsien, Tsai Ming-Liang

Bibliography:

*   Chris Berry and Feyi Lu (eds.), _Island on the Edge: Taiwan New Cinema and After_, Hong Kong: Hong University Press, 2005
*   Emilie Yueh-Yu Yeh and Darrel William Davis (eds.), _Taiwan Film Directors: A Treasure Island_, New York: Columbia University Press, 2005

Week 15: 1990s-2000s: David Lynch

Bibliography:

*   Justus Nieland, _David Lynch_, Urbana: University of Illinois Press, 2012
*   Allister Mactaggart, _The Film Paintings of David Lynch: Challenging Film Theory_, Bristol, UK : Intellect, c2010 
*   Anthony Todd, _Authorship and the Films of David Lynch_. _Aesthetic Receptions in Contemporary Hollywood_, London: I.B. Tauris, 2012

Week 16: Christopher Nolan

Bibliography:

*   Todd McGowan, _The Fictional Christopher Nolan_, Austin: The University of Texas Press, 2012
*   Tom Shone, _The Nolan Variations. The Movies, Mysteries, and Marvels of Christopher Nolan_, New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 2020

Week 17-18: Discussion 

**General Bibliography**

*   Erik Barnouw, _Documentary: A History of the Non-Fiction Film_, New York : Oxford University Press, 1993
*   David Bordwell, Kristin Thompson, _Film Art: An Introduction_, New York : McGraw-Hill, c2010
*   Sarah Casey Benyahia and Claire Mortimer, _Doing Film Studies: A Subject Guide for Students_, London: Routledge, 2013
*   James Chapman, Mark Glancy and Sue Harper  (ed.), _The New Film History: Sources, Methods, Approaches_, Basingstoke and New York: Palgrave Macmillan, 2007
*   David A. Cook, _A History of Narrative Film_, New York: W.W. Norton, 2004
*   Josef Früchtl, _The Impertinent Self: A Heroic History of Modernity and Film_, Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2009
*   William Guynn (ed.), _The Routledge Companion to Film History_, London and New York: Routledge, 2011
*   Marnie Hughes-Warrington (ed.), _The History on Film Reader_, London and New York: Routledge, 2009
*   James Monaco, _How to Read a Film: Movies, Media, and Beyond: Art, Technology, Language, History, Theory_, Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 2009
*   Jill Nelmes (ed.), _An Introduction to Film Studies_, London: Routledge, 2012
*   Joanna Paul, _Film and the Classical Epic Tradition_, Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2013
*   Robert Sklar, _Film: An International History of the Medium_, New York: H.N. Abrams, 1993
*   Nicolas Tredell (ed.), _Cinemas of the Mind: a Critical History of Film Theory_, Cambridge: Icon Books and Totem Books, 2002
*   Wheeler Winston Dixon & Gwendolyn Audrey Foster, _A Short History of Film_, New Brunswick, Rutgers University Press, 2008
